trans-unit.source: Provides Internet Protocol (IP) statistical data.

This class is used by the <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPGlobalProperties.GetIPv4GlobalStatistics%2A> and <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPGlobalProperties.GetIPv6GlobalStatistics%2A> methods to return IP traffic information.
The Internet protocol is used to move IP packets from a source computer to a destination computer.
IP also handles dividing a packet that is too large into multiple packets that are small enough for transport, in a process known as fragmentation.
The properties in this class correlate to the Management Information Base objects for IP defined in IETF RFC 2011.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPGlobalStatistics"></xref> class.
This constructor can be called only by classes that derive from <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPGlobalStatistics>.
Gets the default time-to-live (TTL) value for Internet Protocol (IP) packets.
The TTL value is reported as the number of routing nodes that can forward a packet before it is discarded.
Each node decrements the current TTL value in a packet before forwarding it.
If the TTL value reaches zero, the packet is deemed undeliverable and is discarded.
Note that when a packet travels from one node to another, this is also known as a "hop".
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the TTL.
Gets a <xref href="System.Boolean"></xref> value that specifies whether Internet Protocol (IP) packet forwarding is enabled.
This value determines whether the computer forwards IP datagrams destined for another computer.
Typically, routers forward packets and host computers do not.
A <xref href="System.Boolean"></xref> value that specifies whether packet forwarding is enabled.
Gets the number of network interfaces.
The data returned by this property includes loopback interfaces.
Network interfaces are also known as network adapters.

An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value containing the number of network interfaces for the address family used to obtain this <xref href="System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPGlobalStatistics"></xref> instance.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) addresses assigned to the local computer.
The data returned by this property includes addresses of pseudo network interfaces such as tunnels.

If this instance was obtained by calling <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPGlobalProperties.GetIPv4GlobalStatistics%2A>, this property returns the number of IPv4 addresses assigned to the local computer.

Similarly, if this instance was obtained by calling <xref:System.Net.NetworkInformation.IPGlobalProperties.GetIPv6GlobalStatistics%2A>, this property returns the number of IPv6 addresses assigned to the local computer.

An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that indicates the number of IP addresses assigned to the address family (Internet Protocol version 4 or Internet Protocol version 6) described by this object.
Gets the number of routes in the Internet Protocol (IP) routing table.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of routes in the routing table.
Gets the number of outbound Internet Protocol (IP) packets.
The number of outbound packets does not include the number of packets that have been forwarded.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of outgoing packets.
Gets the number of routes that have been discarded from the routing table.
One possible reason for discarding a valid routing table entry could be to free buffer space for other entries.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of valid routes that have been discarded.
Gets the number of transmitted Internet Protocol (IP) packets that have been discarded.
The data returned by this property does not include packets discarded because of errors that made the packets undeliverable.
Packets included in this data are typically discarded due to network issues, such as insufficient buffer space.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of outgoing packets that have been discarded.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets for which the local computer could not determine a route to the destination address.
IP packets that fall into this category are discarded.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the number of packets that could not be sent because a route could not be found.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets that could not be fragmented.
Packets that exceed the maximum size for IP transport are broken into fragments and reassembled at the destination.

The value returned by this property indicates the number of packets that needed to be fragmented for IP transport but could not be because the packet header specified that the packet not be fragmented.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of packets that required fragmentation but had the "Don't Fragment" bit set.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets that required reassembly.
Packets that exceed the maximum size for IP transport are broken into fragments and reassembled at the destination.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of packet reassemblies required.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets that were not successfully reassembled.
Packets that exceed the maximum size for IP transport are broken into fragments and reassembled at the destination.
If some fragments are lost or do not arrive within a set time, the reassembly does not succeed.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of packets that could not be reassembled.
Gets the maximum amount of time within which all fragments of an Internet Protocol (IP) packet must arrive.
Packets that exceed the maximum size for IP transport are broken into fragments and reassembled at the destination.
If all fragments that make up a fragmented IP packet do not arrive within the allowed time, the packet is discarded.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the maximum number of milliseconds within which all fragments of a packet must arrive to avoid being discarded.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets fragmented.
Packets that exceed the maximum size for IP transport are broken into fragments and reassembled at the destination.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of fragmented packets.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets reassembled.
Session layer packets that exceed the maximum size for IP transport are broken into fragments and reassembled at the destination.
If some fragments are lost or do not arrive within a set time, the reassembly does not succeed.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of fragmented packets that have been successfully reassembled.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets received.
The value returned by this property includes packets received in error.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of IP packets received.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets delivered.
The value returned by this property includes Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) messages.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of IP packets delivered.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets that have been received and discarded.
The value returned by this property includes only those packets that were discarded even though they did not contain errors that prevented reassembly or delivery.
Typically, packets in this category are discarded because of insufficient buffer space.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of incoming packets that have been discarded.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets forwarded.
If the local computer is not a router, the value returned by this property includes packets that were successfully source-routed via the local computer.
Source routing is an IP option whereby the source of the packet can specify the route to the destination address.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of forwarded packets.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets with address errors that were received.
The value returned by this property includes packets discarded for address related issues in the header fields, such as invalid addresses.
If packet forwarding is not enabled, the value returned by this property includes packets that were discarded because the destination address was not a local address.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of IP packets received with errors in the address portion of the header.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets with header errors that were received.
The value returned by this property includes packets discarded for non-address related issues in the header fields, such as bad checksums, time-to-live value exceeded, and incorrect IP options.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that specifies the total number of IP packets received and discarded due to errors in the header.
Gets the number of Internet Protocol (IP) packets received on the local machine with an unknown protocol in the header.
The protocol field in the IP header indicates the next-level protocol used in the data portion of the IP datagram.
If the protocol is not recognized, the data cannot be passed to the correct application.
An <xref href="System.Int64"></xref> value that indicates the total number of IP packets received with an unknown protocol.
